The observations from the security review point to several architectural aspects, but one notable concern is that the load balancer has only a single server assigned. This setup could lead to a single point of failure, which impacts the system's ability to remain operational if that server goes down.

Option C: Availability is the most pertinent concern that needs to be addressed.

Ensuring availability typically involves having multiple servers or instances behind a load balancer to provide redundancy and failover capabilities. This approach enhances the system's resilience, ensuring that services remain available even if one server experiences issues. Therefore, to improve availability, the architecture should include additional servers or instances to handle the traffic, thus preventing downtime in case of failure.

Selected Answer: C
After thorough research about the question, I changed my answer to C Availability: This is the primary issue. A single server means the system is not highly available (no failover). The single server behind the load balancer is a critical availability risk. Best practice is to have multiple servers to ensure redundancy and failover. A single server behind the load balancer represents a single point of failure. If that server goes down, the entire application becomes unavailable. This directly impacts availability. A load balancer is typically used to distribute traffic across multiple servers to ensure the system can handle high traffic and remain available even if one server fails.

questions.question_text: A company uses a CSP to provide a front end for its new payment system offering. The new offering is currently certified as PCI compliant. In order for the integrated solution to be compliant, the customer:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
o Content Security Policy (CSP) can be considered partially PCI compliant as it can help meet certain requirements of the PCI Data Security Standard (PCI DSS), particularly regarding script authorization on payment pages, but it alone is not enough to achieve full PCI compliance and needs to be implemented alongside other security measures.
o While the CSP is PCI compliant, the customer still needs to ensure that any of their systems interacting with the payment system and handling cardholder data are also PCI compliant. This is because the PCI compliance certification only covers the specific services provided by the CSP, not the customer's entire infrastructure. The customer's portion of the integrated solution needs to be secure as well to maintain overall compliance.

Selected Answer: D
In a Payment Card Industry (PCI) context, even if a company is using a Cloud Service Provider (CSP) to host or manage part of its system, the company remains responsible for ensuring that its in-scope systems (systems that store, process, or transmit payment card data) are PCI compliant. The certification of the offering as PCI compliant typically refers to the specific parts of the environment where payment card data is processed or stored, but it does not automatically extend to all other parts of the company’s environment. Thus, the company must ensure that all systems involved in the payment processing solution that are considered in-scope for PCI DSS requirements are compliant. The CSP may be responsible for ensuring that their infrastructure and services (such as cloud-based storage or serverless services) meet PCI compliance standards, but the customer still needs to confirm that their systems that interact with this service are also compliant.

Selected Answer: D
When using a cloud service provider (CSP) for a payment system, compliance with PCI DSS (Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard) is a shared responsibility between the customer and the CSP. While the CSP might be PCI-compliant for its infrastructure or services, the customer is still responsible for ensuring that in-scope systems (those processing, transmitting, or storing cardholder data) in their environment are also PCI compliant.

Ans D. In the context of using a Cloud Service Provider (CSP) for a PCI-compliant payment system, the correct option is D. must ensure in-scope systems for the new offering are also PCI compliant. While the CSP may be PCI compliant, the customer is responsible for ensuring that their own systems and processes that interact with the payment system also meet PCI compliance requirements.
